5.0% S. Asian or mixed

0.6% Chinese and other |population_density_blank2_km2 = |population_density_blank2_sq_mi = |timezone = [[Greenwich Mean Time]] |utc_offset = +0 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |latd = 53 |latm = 29 |lats = 24 |latNS = N |longd = 2 |longm = 05 |longs = 39 |longEW = W |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_m = 151 |elevation_ft = |postal_code_type = Postcode |postal_code = [[OL postcode area|OL]], [[SK postcode area|SK]], [[M postcode area|M]] |area_code = 0161 / 01457 |blank_name = [[ISO 3166-2:GB|ISO 3166-2]] |blank_info = GB-TAM |blank1_name = [[ONS coding system|ONS code]] |blank1_info = 00BT |blank2_name = [[British national grid reference system|OS grid reference]] |blank2_info = {{gbmappingsmall|SJ931997}} |blank3_name = [[Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics|NUTS]] 3 |blank3_info = UKD31 |blank4_name = |blank4_info = |website = [http://www.tameside.gov.uk/ www.tameside.gov.uk] |footnotes = }} The '''Metropolitan Borough of Tameside''' is a [[metropolitan borough]] of [[Greater Manchester]] in [[North West England]]. It is named after the [[River Tame, Greater Manchester|River Tame]] which flows through the borough and spans the towns of [[Ashton-under-Lyne]], [[Audenshaw]], [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]], [[Droylsden]], [[Dukinfield]], [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]], [[Mossley]] and [[Stalybridge]]. Its western border is approximately {{convert|4|mi|km|1}} east of [[Manchester city centre]]. It borders [[Derbyshire]] to the east, the [[Metropolitan Borough of Oldham]] to the north, the [[Metropolitan Borough of Stockport]] to the south, and the [[Manchester|City of Manchester]] to the west. Tameside has a population of 214,400.{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/statbase/ssdataset.asp?vlnk=9666&More=Y |author=Anon |title=Population estimates 2006 by district |publisher=Statistics.gov.uk |date=2007-08-21 |accessdate=2007-12-21}} The history of the area extends back to the [[Stone Age]]. There are over 300 [[listed building]]s in Tameside and three [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]]s, which includes [[Buckton Castle|a castle]] of national importance. The settlements in Tameside were small townships centred around agriculture until the advent of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. The towns of the borough grew and became involved in the cotton industry, which dominated the local economy. The current borough was created in 1974 as part of the provisions of the [[Local Government Act 1972]]. Since then the area has been administered by Tameside Borough Council, which has been judged by the [[Audit Commission]] to be "performing strongly". ==History== The history of the area stretches back up to 10,000 years; there are 22 [[Mesolithic]] sites in Tameside, the oldest dating to around 8,000 BC; 21 of the 22 sites are in the hilly uplands in the north east of the borough.Nevell (1992), pp. 21, 25. Evidence of [[Neolithic]]Nevell (1992), pp. 29–31. and [[Bronze Age]] activity is more limited in the borough, although the Bronze Age Stalybridge Cairn is the most complete prehistoric funerary monument in the borough.Nevell (1992), pp. 40–41. The people in the area changed from hunter-gatherers to farmers around 2500 BC–1500 BC due to climate change.Nevell (1992), p. 34. Werneth Low is the most likely [[Iron Age]] farmstead site in the borough, probably dating to the late 1st millennium BC.Nevell (1992), p. 51. Before the Roman conquest of Britain in the 1st century AD, the area was probably part of the territory of the [[Brigantes]], the [[Celts|Celtic]] tribe controlling most of what is now north west England.Nevell (1992), p. 55. The area came under control of the [[Roman Empire]] in the second half of the 1st century. Roads through the area were established from [[Ardotalia]] [[castra|fort]] in [[Derbyshire]] to [[Mamucium]] (Manchester) west of Tameside and [[Castleshaw Roman fort]] in the north.Nevell (1992), p. 56–59. Romano-British finds in the borough include a [[bog body]] in Ashton Moss, occupation sites at Werneth Low, Harridge Pike, Roe Cross, and Mottram.Nevell (1992), p. 60. A 4th century coin hoard was found in Denton and is one of only four hoards from the 4th century in the Mersey [[river basin|basin]].Nevell (1992), p. 75. A Byzantine coin from the 6th or 7th centuries, also found in Denton, indicates continued or renewed occupation once the Romans left Britain in the early 5th century.Nevell (1992), p. 76. Nico Ditch, an earthwork stretching from Stretford to Ashton-under-Lyne, is evidence of [[Anglo-Saxon]] activity in Tameside. It was probably dug between the 7th and 9th centuries and may have been used as a boundary between the kingdoms of [[Mercia]] and [[Northumbria]].Nevell (1992), pp. 77–83. Further evidence of Anglo-Saxon era activity in Tameside comes from the derivation of settlement names from [[Old English]] such as -''tun'', meaning farmstead, and ''leah'' meaning clearing.Nevell (1992), p. 85. According to the [[Domesday Survey]] of 1086, Tameside was divided into four [[manorialism|manors]], those of Tintwistle, Hollingworth, Werneth, and Mottram. The land east or the River Tame was in the [[Hundreds of Cheshire|Hundred of Hamestan]] in Cheshire and held by the [[Earl of Chester]] while to the west of the river was in the [[Salford (hundred)|Hundred of Salford]] under [[Roger the Poitevin|Roger de Poitevin]].Nevell (1991), pp. 7–9. These manors were divided to create further manors, so that by the 13th century. Most of them were owned by local families and remained in the hands of the same families until the 16th century.Nevell (1991), pp. 46–47. Manorialism continued as the main for of administration and governance until the mid-19th century.Nevell (1993), p. 13. The Industrial Revolution had a significant impact on Tameside; the area, whose main towns had previously been Ashton-under-Lyne and Mottram-in-Longdendale, was transformed from a collection of the rural, farming communities into [[mill town]]s. The towns of Ashton-under-Lyne, Dukinfield, Hyde, Mossley and Stalybridge have been described as "amongst the most famous mills towns in the North West".McNiel and Nevell (2005), p. 54. With only a brief interruption for the [[Lancashire Cotton Famine]] of 1861 to 1865, factories producing and processing textiles were the main industry in Tameside from the late-18th century until the mid-20th century.Nevell (1993), p. 170. In 1964, Dukinfield Borough Council convened a meeting of neighbouring local authorities with the aim of formulating a policy of cross-authority social improvement for the districts in the Tame Valley. Following [[deindustrialisation]], the area had suffered "gross-neglect" and had large areas of housing unsuitable for human habitation.{{Harvnb|Frangopulo|1977|p=168}}. This joint enterprise comprised the nine districts that would become Tameside ten years later, plus the [[County Borough of Stockport]]. This collective agreed on creating "a linear park in the valley [of the River Tame] for the use of the townspeople and as a major recreational resource within the Manchester metropolis". Tameside was created on 1 April 1974, by the [[Local Government Act 1972]] as one of the ten metropolitan districts of Greater Manchester. It took over the local government functions of nine districts which were formerly in the [[Administrative counties of England|administrative counties]] of [[Lancashire]] and of [[Cheshire]].HMSO. Local Government Act 1972. 1972 c.70 In 1986 Tameside effectively became a [[unitary authority]] with the abolition of the [[Greater Manchester County Council]]. A name for the metropolitan borough proved problematic. The [[Redcliffe-Maud Report]] had used the name Ashton-Hyde, but double-barrelled names were prohibited for the new districts. Had Ashton-under-Lyne been a [[county borough]], or had had a less common name, "it might have been chosen as the new name" for the new district. The eight other towns objected, adamant that "a new name should be found". Thirty suggestions were put forward, including Brigantia, Clarendon, Hartshead, Kayborough, Tame, Ninetowns, and West Pennine, with Hartshead (with reference to [[Hartshead Pike]]) being the most popular throughout most of the consultation period. However, the name Tameside (with reference to the River Tame) won 15 votes to Hartshead's 10 in a final stage of voting.{{Harvnb|Clark|1973|p=102}}. The borough underwent a boundary review in 2002. The review altered the areas covered by some [[ward (division)|wards]] to ensure councillors represented roughly equal numbers.{{cite web |title=Boundary shake-up means 'all out' vote |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |url=http://www.tamesideadvertiser.co.uk/news/s/382238_boundary_shakeup_means_all_out_vote |date=29 August 2002}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Between 12 October 2006–8 January 2007, a dispersal order was enforced in the Dukinfield and Newton Hyde areas of the borough. The move was designed to reduce anti-social behaviour. A representative of Stalybridge police post said "Due to the serious nature of recent incidents in Dukinfield and Newton Hyde involving a number of confrontations between large groups of youths, the decision has been made to introduce a Dispersal Order".{{cite web|title=The Tameside Citizen: Orders to tackle crime and disorder |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/thecitizen/issue39/page3 |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=16 January 2007}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. ==Geography== [[Image:Werneth Low.jpg|right|thumb|Werneth Low with the [[Greater Manchester Urban Area]] in the background.]] Tameside is bordered by the [[metropolitan borough]]s of [[Metropolitan Borough of Stockport|Stockport]] and [[Metropolitan Borough of Oldham|Oldham]] to the south and north respectively, the [[city of Manchester]] to the west and the [[borough]] of [[High Peak, Derbyshire|High Peak]] in [[Derbyshire]] to the east. Tameside features flat lowlands in the west and highlands in the east where the western edge of the [[Pennines]] encroaches on the borough.Nevell (1992), p. 8. The hills in the east include [[Hartshead Pike]] and [[Werneth Low]] which is also a country park. As well as coal measures running north-south through the centre of the borough, there are areas of peat in the north east and there are large areas of [[boulder clay]] all over Tameside.Nevell (1992), p. 10. Ashton Moss is a [[peat bog]] covering about {{convert|107|ha|acre}} and Denton Moor is an area of about {{convert|81|ha|acre}} of peat.Nevell (1992), p. 11. [[Image:Stalybridge towards Manchester.jpg|thumb|left|A view over Tameside, towards [[Manchester city centre]].]] Waterways in Tameside include the rivers [[River Medlock|Medlock]] and [[River Etherow|Etherow]], which form parts of Tameside's western and eastern boundaries respectively, and the River Tame crosses the borough north to south, giving Tameside its name. The [[Ashton Canal]], the [[Hollinwood Branch Canal]], the [[Huddersfield Narrow Canal]], and the Peak Forest Canal all run through the borough. There are also several [[reservoir]]s, including the [[Audenshaw Reservoirs]]. [[Green belt|Greenspace]] accounts for 63.5% of the Tameside's total area, domestic buildings and gardens comprise 17.4%, and the rest is made up of roads and non-domestic buildings.{{cite web |title=Tameside physical environment |publisher=Statistics.gov.uk |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=8&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1211747935609&enc=1 |accessdate=2008-05-25 }} Localities within the boundaries of Tameside include: [[Ashton-under-Lyne]], [[Audenshaw]], [[Broadbottom]], [[Carrbrook]], [[Copley, Greater Manchester|Copley]], [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]], [[Droylsden]], [[Dukinfield]], [[Flowery Field]], [[Gee Cross]], [[Godley, Greater Manchester|Godley]], [[Godley Green]], [[Guide Bridge]], [[Hartshead Green]], [[Hattersley]], [[Haughton Green]], [[Hazelhurst, Tameside|Hazelhurst]], [[Heyrod]], [[Hollingworth]], [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]], [[Landslow Green]], [[Luzley]], [[Millbrook, Greater Manchester|Millbrook]], [[Mossley]], [[Mottram in Longdendale]], [[Newton, Hyde|Newton]], [[Park Bridge]], [[Roe Cross]], [[Stalybridge]], [[Warhill]], and [[Woolley Bridge]]. ==Governance== ===Parliamentary constituencies=== The residents of the Tameside are represented in the [[United Kingdom Parliament]] by [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|Members of Parliament]] (MPs) for three separate parliamentary constituencies. [[Ashton-under-Lyne (UK Parliament constituency)|Ashton-under-Lyne]], which also includes parts of the [[Metropolitan Borough of Oldham]], is represented by Mr. [[David Heyes]] MP ([[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]).{{cite news | title = Ashton-under-Lyne constituency election results | publisher = Guardian.co.uk | url = http://politics.guardian.co.uk/hoc/constituency/0,,-680,00.html |accessdate=2007-12-26 | location=London}} [[Denton and Reddish (UK Parliament constituency)|Denton and Reddish]], which also covers parts of the [[Metropolitan Borough of Stockport]], is represented by Mr. [[Andrew Gwynne]] MP (Labour).{{cite news | title = Denton and Reddish constituency election results | publisher = Guardian.co.uk | url = http://politics.guardian.co.uk/hoc/constituency/0,,-869,00.html |accessdate=2007-12-26 | location=London}} [[Stalybridge and Hyde (UK Parliament constituency)|Stalybridge and Hyde]], which is entirely within Tameside, is represented by Mr. [[Jonathan Reynolds]] MP (Labour).{{cite news | title = Stalybridge constituency election results | publisher = Guardian.co.uk | url = http://politics.guardian.co.uk/hoc/constituency/0,,-1330,00.html |accessdate=2007-12-26 | location=London}} Tameside is part of the [[North West England (European Parliament constituency)|North West England]] constituency in the [[European Parliament]]. North West England elects eight MEPs, as at 2009 made up of three Conservatives, two from the Labour Party, one member of the [[United Kingdom Independence Party]], one [[Liberal Democrats|Liberal Democrat]], and one member of the BNP.{{cite news |title=European Election 2009 Results |publisher=news.bbc.co.uk |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/elections/euro/09/html/ukregion_34.stm |accessdate=2009-11-11 | date=2009-04-19}} ===Council=== As of the [[Tameside Council election, 2008|2008 local elections]], Tameside Council is controlled by [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] with the majority of 44 seats, second is the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative party]] with 10 seats, third is taken by 3 [[independent (politician)|independents]] in Mossley. The Leader of the Council is Councillor Kieran Quinn. Tameside Borough Council was assessed by the [[Audit Commission]] and judged to be "improving strongly" in providing services for local people. Overall the council was awarded "four star" status meaning it was "performing strongly" and "well above minimum requirements", putting it in the top 38% of all local authorities.{{cite web |title=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council comprehensive performance assessment (CPA) scorecard 2007 |publisher=[[Audit Commission]] |url=http://cpa.audit-commission.gov.uk/STCCScorecard.aspx?TaxID=108243 |year=2007}} Retrieved on 8 September 2008. [[Civil parish]]es form the bottom tier of local government; the parish councils are involved in planning, management of town and parish centres, and promoting tourism.{{cite web |title = What is a town, parish or community council? |author = National Association of Local Councils |publisher = nalc.gov.uk |url = http://www.nalc.gov.uk/About_NALC/What_is_a_parish_or_town_council/What_is_a_council.aspx |accessdate = 2008-01-26 }} [[Mossley]] is the only civil parish in Tameside, in 2001 9,856 people lived there, 4.6% of the borough's population.{{cite web | title =Mossley civil parish census data | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=790588&c=Mossley&d=16&e=15&g=355915&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1203604074412&enc=1&dsFamilyId=781 | accessdate = 2008-02-21 }} Prior to becoming a civil parish, it was a [[Municipal Borough]]. The unparished areas are: [[Ashton-under-Lyne]] (Municipal Borough), [[Audenshaw]] ([[Urban District]]), [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]] (Urban District), [[Droylsden]] (Urban District), [[Dukinfield]] (Municipal Borough), [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]] (Municipal Borough), [[Longdendale]] (Urban District), and [[Stalybridge]] (Municipal Borough). The status of each area prior to 1974 is shown in brackets. An urban district was a type of local government district which covered an urbanised area. Ashton-under-Lyne, Audenshaw, Denton, Droylsden, and Mossley were previously in Lancashire and Dukinfield, Hyde, Longdendale, and Stalybridge were in Cheshire. {| class="wikitable" |+'''[[Party Democrats (UK)|Lib Dems]] | style="text-align: right" | ''1'' | style="text-align: right" | ''0'' | style="text-align: right" | ''0'' |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |} ==Demography== {| class="wikitable" id="toc" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; width: 40%; font-size: 90%;" cellspacing="5" !colspan="4"|'''Tameside Compared''' |- |'''[[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 UK Census]]'''||'''Tameside'''||'''Greater Manchester'''||'''England''' |- |Total population||213,043||2,514,757||49,138,831 |- |White||94.6%||91.2%||90.9% |- |Asian||4.0%||5.6%||4.6% |- |Black||0.3%||1.2%||2.3% |} As of the [[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 UK census]], the Metropolitan Borough of Tameside had a total population of 213,043.{{cite web | title =Tameside Metropolitan Borough key statistics | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url =http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1198202002570&enc=1 | accessdate = 2007-12-21 }} Of the 89,981 households in Tameside, 35.7% were married couples living together, 31.0% were one-person households, 7.8% were [[cohabitation|co-habiting]] couples and 9.3% were lone parents, following a similar trend to the rest of England.{{cite web | title =Tameside Metropolitan Borough household data | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1198202583539&enc=1&dsFamilyId=165 | accessdate = 2007-12-21 }} The population density was {{convert|2065|/km2|/sqmi|abbr=on}}{{cite web | title =Tameside Metropolitan Borough population density | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1198202583570&enc=1&dsFamilyId=789 | accessdate = 2007-12-21 }} and for every 100 females, there were 94.2 males. Of those aged 16â74 in Tameside, 35.2% had no [[Education in England#Specialist qualifications|academic qualifications]], significantly higher than 28.9% in all of England. 4.8% of Tameside's residents were born outside the United Kingdom, significantly lower than the national average of 9.2%.{{cite web | title =Tameside Metropolitan Borough country of birth data | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1198202583523&enc=1&dsFamilyId=85 | accessdate = 2007-12-21 }} The largest minority group was Asian, at 4.0% of the population.{{cite web | title =Tameside Metropolitan Borough ethnic group data | publisher = Statistics.gov.uk | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1198202583523&enc=1&dsFamilyId=87 | accessdate = 2007-12-21 }} In 1841, 8.5% of Tameside's population was [[middle class]] compared to 14% in England and Wales; this increased to 13.1% in 1931 (15% nationally) and 37.0% in 2001 (48% nationally). From 1841 to 1991, the [[working class]] population of Tameside and across the country was in decline, falling steadily from 58.0% (36% nationally) to 22.8% in 1991 (21% nationally). It has since increased slightly, up to 32.9% (26% nation-wide). The rest of the population was made up of clerical workers and skilled manual workers.{{cite web |url=http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/data_cube_table_page.jsp?data_theme=T_SOC&data_cube=N_RGSOC_G&u_id=10056871&c_id=10001043&add=Y |title=Tameside social class |publisher=Vision of Britain}} Retrieved on 6 September 2008.
Â·{{cite web |url=http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/data_cube_table_page.jsp?data_theme=T_SOC&data_cube=N_RGSOC_G&u_id=10061325&c_id=10001043&add=Y |title=England social class |publisher=Vision of Britain}} Retrieved on 6 September 2008. ===Population change=== Although Tameside has only existed as a Metropolitan Borough since 1974, the table below details the population change – including the percentage change since the last census 10 years earlier – in the area since 1801 using figures from the towns, villages, and [[Civil parishes in England|civil parish]]es that would later become constituent parts of Tameside. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;width:70%;border:0px;text-align:center;line-height:120%;" ! colspan="22" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;"|[[Population growth]] in Tameside since 1801 |- ! style="background: #99CCCC; color: #000080" height="17" | Year ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1801 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1811 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1821 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1831 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1841 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1851 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1861 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1911 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1921 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1931 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color:#000080;" | 1941 ! style="background: #FFFFFF; color: #000080" height="17" | % change | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | – | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +31.4 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +66.8 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +40.9 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +62.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +15.6 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +7.6 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +11.1 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | -1.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | -1.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +4.4 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +4.4 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +3.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +3.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | -1.8 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | +1.3 | style="background: #FFFFFF; color: black;" | -3.1 |- | colspan="22" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;"|'''Source: '''[http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/data_cube_table_page.jsp?data_theme=T_POP&data_cube=N_TPop&u_id=10056871&c_id=10001043&add=N A Vision of Britain through Time] |} ===Religion=== {| class="wikitable" id="toc" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; width: 40%; font-size: 90%;" cellspacing="5" !colspan="4"|'''Religion in Tameside''' |- |'''[[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 UK Census]]'''||'''Tameside'''||'''[[North West England]]'''||'''England''' |- |Population||213,043||6,729,764||49,138,831 |- |Christian||75.5%||78.0%||71.7% |- |Muslim||2.5%||3.0%||3.1% |- |Hindu||1.4%||0.4%||1.1% |- |No religion||12.1%||10.5%||14.6% |} {{See also|List of churches in Greater Manchester}} As of the 2001 UK census, 75.5% of Tameside's residents reported themselves as being Christian, 2.5% Muslim, 1.4% Hindu, and 0.1% Buddhist. 12.1% had no religion, 0.2% had an alternative religion and 8.1% did not state their religion. Tameside is covered by the Catholic Dioceses of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Shrewsbury|Shrewsbury]] and [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Salford|Salford]],{{cite web |title=Parishes of the Catholic Diocese of Shrewsbury |url=http://www.dioceseofshrewsbury.org |publisher=Dioceseofshrewsbury.org | accessdate = 2008-01-17}}{{cite web | title=Parishes of the Diocese |publisher= Salforddiocese.org.uk |url=http://www.salforddiocese.org.uk/parishes/masstimes.html |accessdate=2008-01-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080111021859/http://www.salforddiocese.org.uk/parishes/masstimes.html |archivedate = January 11, 2008}} and the Church of England [[Anglican Diocese of Manchester|Diocese of Manchester]].{{cite web | title = The Church of England Diocese of Manchester | url = http://www.manchester.anglican.org/default.asp | publisher = Manchester.anglican.org | accessdate = 2008-01-17}} There are two Grade I listed churches in Tameside, [[St Anne's Church, Haughton Green|St Anne's Church]], in [[Haughton, Greater Manchester|Haughton]], was built in 1881 in the [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] style by J Medland Taylor.{{cite web|title=Church of St Anne|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=212705 |publisher=Images of England|accessdate=2007-12-22}} [[St Michael and All Angels' Church, Ashton-under-Lyne|St Michael and All Angels' Church]] in [[Ashton-under-Lyne]] is a 15th century parish church which was virtually rebuilt in the 19th century. A church on the site dates back to at least 1262.{{cite web|title=Church of St Michael and All Angels|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=212681 |publisher=Images of England|accessdate=2007-12-22}}Nevell (1991), p. 121, 135. [[St Lawrence's Church, Denton|St Lawrence's Church]], in Denton, is a Grade II* listed building and a timber framed church. It was remodelled by J Medland Taylor in 1872.Nevell (1991), p. 123â124. ==Economy== [[Image:Ikea Ashton-under-Lyne 2008.jpg|thumb|right|[[IKEA]]'s store in Ashton-under-Lyne, which opened in 2006, was their first in a town centre.]] The [[Ashton Arcades]] shopping centre opened in 1995. The centre covers {{convert|13000|m2|sqft}} on two floors with over 40 shops. In 2006, after failing twice to gain permission to develop a site in the neighbouring borough of [[Metropolitan Borough of Stockport|Stockport]], [[IKEA]] announced plans to build its first town centre-store in Ashton-under-Lyne. The store is expected to create 500 new jobs as well as attract other businesses to the area.{{cite web |title=Ikea's superstore plans approved |publisher=BBC Online |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/4604024.stm |date=11 January 2006}} Retrieved on 3 September 2008. The store opened on 19 October 2006 and covers {{convert|27500|m2|sqft}} At the time of its creation, the store was the tallest in Britain.{{cite web |title=IKEA's finally here |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/lifestyle/health_and_beauty/style/s/225/225588_ikeas_finally_here.html |author=Emma Unsworth |date=16 October 2006}} Retrieved on 3 September 2008. Life science industries have been identified as growth industries in Greater Manchester and are concentrated in Oldham and Tameside.{{cite web |title=Promoting a Dynamic Economy |publisher=Greater Manchester e-Government Partnership |url=http://www.gmep.org.uk/ccm/content/agma/promoting-a-dynamic-economy.en;jsessionid=64C7688F205BEE012F17A5E3001818D5}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Average house prices in Tameside are the 7th highest out of the ten metropolitan boroughs in Greater Manchester, 11.9% below the average for the county.{{cite news |title=House prices for Greater Manchester Local Authorities |publisher=BBC News Online |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/in_depth/uk_house_prices/counties/html/county38.stm | date=2010-03-16 | accessdate=2010-04-01}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. {| class="wikitable" id="toc" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; width: 40%; font-size: 90%;" cellspacing="5" !colspan="4"|'''Tameside Compared''' |- |'''[[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 UK Census]]'''||'''Tameside'''||'''[[North West England]]'''||'''England''' |- |Population of working age||152,313||4,839,669||35,532,091 |- |Full time employment||43.5%||38.8%||40.8% |- |Part time employment||11.5%||11.9%||11.8% |- |Self employed||6.5%||7.1%||8.3% |- |Unemployed||3.3%||3.6%||3.3% |- |Retired||13.3%||14.3%||13.5% |} As of the 2001 UK census, Tameside had 152,313 residents aged 16 to 74. 2.0% of these people were students with jobs, 5.7% looking after home or family, 7.9% permanently sick or disabled and 3.2% economically inactive for other reasons.{{cite web |title=Tameside Local Authority economic activity |publisher=Statistics.gov.uk |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=7&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1220287706082&enc=1&dsFamilyId=107}} Retrieved on 1 September 2008. In 2001, of 96,255 residents of Tameside in employment, the industry of employment was 21.7% manufacturing, 10.4% health and social work, 18.2% retail and wholesale, 10.2% property and business services, 7.2% construction, 6.8% transport and communications, 6.4% education, 5.3% public administration and defence, 4.2% finance, 4.0% hotels and restaurants, 0.9% energy and water supply, 0.5% agriculture, and 4.0% other. This was roughly in line with national figures, except for the proportion of jobs in agriculture which is less than half the national average, and property which was also below the national average. Manufacturing was 50% more than the national average.{{cite web |title=Tameside Local Authority industry of employment |publisher=Statistics.gov.uk |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=7&b=276783&c=Tameside&d=13&e=16&g=355472&i=1001x1003x1004&o=1&m=0&r=1&s=1220287706082&enc=1&dsFamilyId=119}} Retrieved on 1 September 2008. {{-}} ==Landmarks== [[Image:Mottram Church 01.JPG|right|thumb|The [[St Michael and All Angels Church, Mottram|Church of St Michael and All Angels]], [[Mottram in Longdendale]], is one of Tameside's Grade II* listed buildings.]] [[Image:View of Buckton Castle from below.jpg|thumb|View of [[Buckton Castle]] from below]] In February 2001, Tameside had one [[Grade I listed buildings in Greater Manchester|Grade I listed buildings]], 19 Grade II*, and 289 Grade II.{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/StatisticsPage/default.aspx?StatsCounty=GREATER%20MANCHESTER|title=Images of England Statistics by County|year=2001|accessdate=2007-12-22}} The number of Grade I listed buildings in Tameside has increased to three, these are [[St Anne's Church, Haughton Green|St Anne's Church]] in [[Haughton, Greater Manchester|Haughton]];{{cite web|title=Church of St Anne|url=http://public.tameside.gov.uk/forms/listedbuildings.asp?propno=0570600202000&district=&address=|publisher=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council|accessdate=2007-12-22}} [[St Michael and All Angels' Church, Ashton-under-Lyne|St Michael and All Angels' Church]] in [[Ashton-under-Lyne]]; and Fairbottom Farm Barn, a 17th century farm building.{{cite web|title=Fairbottom Farm Barn|url=http://public.tameside.gov.uk/forms/listedbuildings.asp?propno=0014800013001&district=&address=|publisher=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council|accessdate=2007-12-22}} In Tameside are three of Greater Manchester's [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater Manchester|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]], Boar Flat, part of [[Dark Peak]],{{cite web |title=Dark Peak |url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003028.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=EnglishNature.org |accessdate=2008-01-27}} the [[Hollinwood Branch Canal]]{{cite web |url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002786.pdf |format=PDF |author= |title=Hollinwood Branch Canal |publisher=EnglishNature.org |accessdate=2008-01-26}} and the [[Huddersfield Narrow Canal]]. The Huddersfield Narrow Canal runs for {{nowrap|{{convert|20|mi|km}}}} from [[Huddersfield]] to [[Ashton-under-Lyne]]; it is protected for its biological interest, and is "the best example of a flowing eutrophic water system in Greater Manchester".{{cite web |url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002803.pdf |format=PDF |author= |title=Huddersfield Narrow Canal |publisher=EnglishNature.org |accessdate=2008-01-26}} There are three [[Scheduled Monuments in Greater Manchester|Scheduled Ancient Monuments]] in the borough, a [[Bronze Age]] [[cairn]] in Stalybridge,{{cite web |title=Monument no. 78454 |url=http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=78454 |publisher=Pastscape.org.uk |accessdate=2008-01-27}} [[Buckton Castle]], and [[Nico Ditch]]. Buckton Castle is a 12th century ringwork near [[Carrbrook]]. It was probably built for William de Neville and was the centre of lordship of [[Longdendale]].Nevell and Walker (1999), p. 95. The castle lay ruinous by 1360, and has been described as "one of England's most important castles".{{cite web |title=The lost castle of Stalybridge |publisher=BBC Online |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/manchester/content/articles/2008/07/23/230708_buckton_castle_feature.shtml |date=30 July 2008}} Retrieved on 9 September 2008. Nico Ditch is an [[Earthworks (engineering)|earthwork]] running from [[Ashton-under-Lyne]] in the east to [[Stretford]] in the west, in the borough of [[Trafford]]. It survives to a depth of {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} in some places and is up to {{convert|4|m|ft}} wide. Tameside also has nine conservation areas: Ashton and Stalybridge town centres; Carrbrook, Copley St.Paul's, and Millbrook in Stalybridge; Fairfield in Droylsden; Mottram-in-Longdendale; [[Portland Basin]]; and St.Anne's in Haughton.{{cite web|title=Appendix 6: Conservation Areas and Scheduled Ancient Monuments (Policies C11 and C30) |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/udp/udp1996/appendix6 |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=November 1992}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. The Museum of the Manchester Regiment is housed in Ashton-under-Lyne's town hall. The museum displays relics related to the [[Manchester Regiment]] including five [[Victoria Cross]]es awarded to members of the regiment.{{cite web|title=Museum of the Manchester Regiment |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/am10929 |publisher=24hourmuseum.org.uk}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Park Bridge Heritage Centre in the Medlock Valley is a museum dedicated to the history of the settlement of Park Bridge and its industry.{{cite web|title=Park Bridge |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/parkbridge |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=13 September 2007}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Broad Mills Heritage Site, in Broadbottom, preserves the remains of an early 19th century textile works.{{cite web|title=Broad Mills Heritage Site: site introduction |url=http://www.broadbottomvillage.com/broad%20mills.htm |publisher=BroadbottomVillage.com}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Art galleries in the borough include Astley Cheetham Art Gallery in Stalybridge and Central Art Gallery in Ashton-under-Lyne.{{cite web|title=Astley Cheetham Art Gallery |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/museumsgalleries/astleycheetham |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=15 October 2007}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008.{{cite web|title=Central Art Gallery |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/centralartgallery |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=16 August 2007}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. Tameside has eight designated [[Local Nature Reserve]]s which are Knott Hill, Hollinwood Branch Canal, Great Wood, Haughton Dale, Hulmes and Hardy Woods, Castle Clough and Cowbury Dale, Hurst Clough and Rocher Vale. Four more are to be designated. {{cite web | url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/countryside/naturereserves| title= Local Nature Reserves - Nature On Your Doorstep| publisher= Tameside Council|accessdate= 27 January 2011}} ==Education== Tameside council announced in 2007 a Â£180M plan to refurbish the borough's schools. The plan involves closing six schools and building six new ones. Overall the number of places available in schools will decrease as the number of school children is expected to decline.{{cite web|title=The Tameside Citizen: Our children's future |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/thecitizen/issue39/page2 |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=16 January 2007}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008. In 2007 Tameside was ranked 61st out of the all the [[Local Education Authority|local education authorities]] in SATs performance – and 5th in Greater Manchester.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/7130024.stm |author= |title=LEA SATs performance 2007 |publisher=BBC Online |date=2007-12-06 |accessdate=2008-01-17}} Authorised absences from and unauthorised absences from Tameside secondary schools in 2006â07 were 6.0% and 0.4%, lower than the national average (7.8% and 1.4%).{{cite web |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/education/07/school_tables/secondary_schools/html/357_5400.stm |author= |title=Tameside schools |publisher=BBC Online |date=2008-01-10 |accessdate=2008-01-17}} In 2007, the Tameside LEA was ranked 100th out of 148 in the country – and 6th in Greater Manchester – based on the percentage of pupils attaining at least 5 A*-C grades at GCSE including maths and English (41.8% compared with the national average of 46.7%).{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/7180228.stm |author= |title=How different LEAs performed 2007 |publisher=BBC Online |date=2008-01-10 |accessdate=2008-01-17}} In 2007, [[Audenshaw School]] was the most successful school in Tameside at both GCSE and A–level; 64% of the pupils gaining five or more GCSEs at A*-C grade including maths and English.{{cite web |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/education/07/school_tables/secondary_schools/html/357_gcse_lea.stm |author= |title=Education results in Tameside 2007 |publisher=BBC Online |date=2008-01-10 |accessdate=2008-01-17}} The secondary schools in Tameside are [[Alder Community High School]], [[All Saints Catholic College]], Astley Sports College, Audenshaw School, Copley High School, [[Denton Community College]], Droylsden Academy, [[Fairfield High School for Girls]], Hyde Technology School, [[Longdendale Community Language College]], [[Mossley Hollins High School]], New Charter Academy, St Damian's RC Science College, St Thomas More RC High School and [[West Hill School]] {{See also|List of schools in Tameside}} ==Transport== [[Image:Fairfield railway station 1.jpg|right|thumb|[[Fairfield railway station (Greater Manchester)|Fairfield railway station]]]] Tameside is served by 13 train stations. [[Denton railway station]] is on the [[Stockport to Stalybridge Line]]. [[Fairfield railway station (Greater Manchester)|Fairfield railway station]], [[Guide Bridge railway station]], [[Hyde Central railway station]], and [[Hyde North railway station]] are all on the [[Hope Valley Line]] between [[Sheffield]] and Manchester. [[Broadbottom railway station]], [[Flowery Field railway station]], [[Godley railway station]], Guide Bridge railway station, [[Hattersley railway station]], and [[Newton for Hyde railway station]] are served by the [[Glossop Line]] between Glossop and Manchester. [[Ashton-under-Lyne railway station]], [[Mossley railway station]], and [[Stalybridge railway station]] are on the [[Huddersfield Line]]. Work on an extension of the [[Manchester Metrolink]] costing Â£260M is expected to begin in 2008. The original plan was to extend the metrolink to Ashton-under-Lyne, but due to reduced funding from the government, the plans were scaled back and it was planned that the extension would go only as far as Droylsden.{{cite web |title=Metrolink wins a 'Little Bang' |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/s/217/217405_metrolink_wins_a_little_bang.html |date=6 July 2006}} Retrieved on 5 September 2008. However, work has started to bring the Metrolink to Ashton centre; currently work has extended to Lord Sheldon Way. Tameside council is responsible for maintaining the public rights of way in the borough, including {{convert|145|mi|km|abbr=on}} of footpaths.{{cite web|title=Rights of way |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/rightsofway |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=16 January 2007}} Retrieved on 5 September 2008. In 2003, the government passed a scheme to create a bypass between the M67 and the A628. The [[Longdendale Bypass]] is expected to cost between Â£240M and Â£315M and although it received support from the communities effected by the bypass in the form of a petition with 9,000 signatures,{{cite web |url=http://child.of.lewin.googlepages.com/costestimates.pdf |title=Highways Agency Major Roads Programme:Updated Scheme Cost Estimates |publisher=Highways Agency |format=PDF |date=16 July}} Retrieved on 2 November 2008.{{cite web |title=Mottram bypass to go ahead |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/s/55/55236_mottram_bypass_to_go_ahead.html |author=Alan Salter |date=1 April 2003}} Retrieved on 6 September 2008. the scheme ran into opposition. A enquiry was launched in 2007, costing Â£15M,{{cite web |title=Tintwistle Hollingworth and Mottram Bypass |publisher=Parliament.uk |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmhansrd/cm080506/text/80506w0006.htm |date=6 May 2008}} Retrieved on 6 September 2008. however the fate of the bypass remains undecided.{{cite web |title=Bypass plans still on track for autumn |work=Tameside Advertiser |url=http://www.tamesideadvertiser.co.uk/news/s/1054548_bypass_plans_still_on_track_for_autumn |author=Alan Salter |date=18 June 2003}} Retrieved on 8 September 2008. ==Twin towns== The Metropolitan Borough of Tameside has formal [[twin towns|twinning links]] with places in China, France, Germany and Zimbabwe.{{cite web|title=Town twinning |url=http://www.tameside.gov.uk/towntwinning |author=Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council |publisher=Tameside.gov.uk |date=27 September 2006}} Retrieved on 4 September 2008 The arrangement with [[Mutare]] in Zimbabwe has been suspended due to the political unrest in that country.[http://www.tameside.gov.uk/executivecabinet/03sept08/item10.pdf Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council : ''Report to Executive Cabinet : 3 September 2008 : Kiagware Project''] Retrieved 8 January 2010 Some localities were originally twinned with a place within the Metropolitan Borough prior to its creation in 1974.{{cite news|url=http://www.francemag.com/Editorial.aspx?page=3073|title=British Towns Twinned with French Towns|work=France
